docs.title: Contribute
docs.text: We're always looking to expand and improve Cheatsheets! If you have a cheat sheet to share or see something that could be improved, feel free to submit a pull request. Let's build a valuable resource for developers together.

docs.title: Python
docs.text:
Abstract

A concise and practical Python cheat sheet covering key syntax, core concepts, and useful features for quick reference.

Contents:

  • Getting Started

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
• Python (python.org)
  • Python Document (docs.python.org)
  • Learn X in Y minutes (learnxinyminutes.com)
  • Regex in python (cheatsheets.zip)

docs.title: Hello World
docs.text:
>>> print("Hello, World!")
Hello, World!

The famous "Hello World" program in Python

docs.title: Variables
docs.text:
age = 18      # age is of type int
name = "John" # name is now of type str
print(name)

Python can't declare a variable without assignment.

docs.title: Data Types
docs.text: str Text int, float, complex Numeric list, tuple, range Sequence dict Mapping set, frozenset Set bool Boolean bytes, bytearray, memoryview Binary

docs.title: Slicing String
docs.text:
>>> msg = "Hello, World!"
>>> print(msg[2:5])
llo

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
mylist = []
mylist.append(1)
mylist.append(2)
for item in mylist:
    print(item) # prints out 1,2

docs.title: If Else
docs.text:
num = 200
if num > 0:
    print("num is greater than 0")
else:
    print("num is not greater than 0")

docs.title: Loops
docs.text:
for item in range(6):
    if item == 3: break
    print(item)
else:
    print("Finally finished!")

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
>>> def my_function():
...     print("Hello from a function")
...
>>> my_function()
Hello from a function

docs.title: File Handling
docs.text:
with open("myfile.txt", "r", encoding='utf8') as file:
    for line in file:
        print(line)

docs.title: Arithmetic
docs.text:
result = 10 + 30 # => 40
result = 40 - 10 # => 30
result = 50 * 5  # => 250
result = 16 / 4  # => 4.0 (Float Division)
result = 16 // 4 # => 4 (Integer Division)
result = 25 % 2  # => 1
result = 5 ** 3  # => 125

The / means quotient of x and y, and the // means floored quotient of x and y, also see StackOverflow

docs.title: Plus-Equals
docs.text:
counter = 0
counter += 10           # => 10
counter = 0
counter = counter + 10  # => 10

message = "Part 1."

# => Part 1.Part 2.
message += "Part 2."

docs.title: f-Strings (Python 3.6+)
docs.text:
>>> website = 'cheatsheets.zip'
>>> f"Hello, {website}"
"Hello, cheatsheets.zip"

>>> num = 10
>>> f'{num} + 10 = {num + 10}'
'10 + 10 = 20'
